newsitem.title: USA: US Southeast spot power supported by tight supply.
newsitem.headline: US Southeast spot power supported by tight supply.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. ended steady Friday against Thursday's levels, continuing to be supported by tight availability, market sources said.
The expected returns of several large nuclear power stations in the Southeastern Electric Reliability Council (SERC) district will likely ease the generating capacity tightness, traders said.
"I'm expecting the market will go down with these units' return. The prices are too high," said a Houston trader.

The three nuclear units, with total capacity over 3,000 megawatts (MW), were expected to resume service by next week: Carolina Power & Light Co's 683 MW Robinson nuclear power unit 2 in Hartsville, S.C., and Tennessee Valley Authority's (TVA) 1,148 MW Sequoyah 2 in Soddy-Daisy, Tenn., and 1,170 MW Watts Bar 1 in Spring City, Tenn.
Temperatures in SERC were predicted to run eight to 12 Fahrenheit degrees below normal over the weekend before returning near normal by mid-week, according to Weather Services Corp.
While Hurricane Lily was not expected to hit Florida, the system was anticipated to push clouds, strong winds and heavy precipitation to parts of the pennisula over the weekend.
At the Georgia/Florida border, firm, peak electricity for Monday was assessed at $22.00-$23.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), down from Thursday's $23.00-$24.00 for Friday delivery.
Firm, off-peak electricity for Monday at the Ga./Fla. border was valued at $15.00-$16.00, up from a quote of $13.50-$14.00 on Thursday.
Up in the northern portion of the TVA system, firm, peak electricity was quoted at $17.00-$18.00, flat from Thursday.
Off-peak, firm power in northern TVA for Monday delivery was widely assessed at $12.00, but a few participants noted offers reached as high as $16.00.
TVA reportedly offered peak, non-firm power for Monday delivery at $20.50, unchanged from Thursday's value for Friday delivery.
